abstract.p: Howard Goldberg column reviews warm weather white wines available at Italian Wine Merchants near New York City's Union Square Park; photo (M)

block.p: Resembling Rome's wine shops -- tranquil refuges from hot piazzas -- the Italian Wine Merchants is an Old World oasis near Union Square Park.

Bottles lining the dark wood shelves, a thick rug, bronze chandelier and baronial table invite thoughtful tasting. If walk-in buyers seem few, it's because the nine-month-old shop, at 108 East 16th Street, does 90-plus percent of its business via phone, fax and e-mail.
Resembling Rome's wine shops -- tranquil refuges from hot piazzas -- the Italian Wine Merchants is an Old World oasis near Union Square Park.

Bottles lining the dark wood shelves, a thick rug, bronze chandelier and baronial table invite thoughtful tasting. If walk-in buyers seem few, it's because the nine-month-old shop, at 108 East 16th Street, does 90-plus percent of its business via phone, fax and e-mail.

To his credit, Sergio Esposito, a former sommelier who is managing partner, turns antsy when vino jargon flows. Emotions and memories govern his wine judgments, he says, along with a bottle's value at table. His partners are the restaurateurs Joseph Bastianich and Mario Batali (Babbo, Becco, Esca, Lupa, Po).

Mr. Esposito spends hours uncovering unknown and underappreciated artisanal wine makers and wines. His warm-weather whites are masterly. Take the nonvintage Prosecco di Valdobbiadene from Ruggeri & C. ($15.20), in the Veneto; lean, with a creamy texture, gently citric, it has the sparkle and finesse of a top Alsace cremant.

The '97 I Frati from Ca dei Frati in Lugana, south of Lake Garda, takes the trebbiano, a neutral grape, and elevates it through a honey-flavored bouquet, pillowy creaminess, a lovely balance between its refreshing acidity and fruit, and hints of melon. The '98 Furore Bianco from Marisa Cuomo on the Amalfi Coast ($17.80) is simply beautiful.
The ambitious '98 Tamellini, a Soave Classico Superiore from the Veneto, rebuts the cliche that all soave need be forever one-dimensional.
Salmon-colored, spilling a tea-rose bouquet, the spare '98 Chiaretto rose from Provenza, in Lombardy, charms with a scrim of raspberry-strawberry flavors ($13.50).
